PT J
AU Gkeredakis, E
   Swan, J
   Nicolini, D
   Tsoukas, H
AF Gkeredakis, Emmanouil
   Swan, Jacky
   Nicolini, Davide
   Tsoukas, Haridimos
TI What is the right thing to do? The constitutive role of organizational
   ethical frameworks in collective ethical sensemaking
SO HUMAN RELATIONS
LA English
DT Article
DE decision making; deliberation; ethical framework; ethical guidelines;
   ethical sensemaking; ethics; moral intuition; moral reasoning;
   sensemaking
ID DECISION-MAKING; WORK; EMERGENCE; FIELD; RESPONSIBILITY; EFFICIENCY;
   EXPERTISE; FAIRNESS; BEHAVIOR; ISSUES
AB In the complex realm of ethical decision making, organizations are increasingly developing comprehensive ethical frameworks as guides. These frameworks prescribe ethical principles and decision-making processes to steer organizational actors toward addressing the elusive question of "what is the right thing to do?" in specific situations. However, the interplay between these prescriptive frameworks and collective processes of ethical sensemaking remains underexplored. Based on an extensive qualitative study within publicly funded healthcare organizations, we examine how organizational actors, confronted with the challenge of making exceptional funding decisions, enact an organizational ethical framework. Our findings reveal the manifold ways through which such a framework both streamlines ethical sensemaking and induces new and unexpected interpretive challenges. These challenges generate ethical equivocality, which decision makers seek to reduce through particular sensegiving interventions, and, on occasion, through problematizing the abstract principles prescribed by the framework, based on what is intuitively felt right in situ. We contribute to the literature by developing a conceptual model of three distinct modes in which organizational actors enact the prescriptions of an ethical framework. Our article sheds new light on the unintended consequences of using organizational ethical frameworks in real-world ethical deliberations.
C1 [Gkeredakis, Emmanouil] Univ Navarra, Pamplona, Spain.
   [Swan, Jacky; Nicolini, Davide; Tsoukas, Haridimos] Univ Warwick, Coventry, England.

AU Ritala, P
AF Ritala, Paavo
TI Grand challenges and platform ecosystems: Scaling solutions for wicked
   ecological and societal problems
SO JOURNAL OF PRODUCT INNOVATION MANAGEMENT
LA English
DT Article
DE ecosystems; grand challenges; platforms; robust action strategies;
   scaling
ID COLLECTIVE ACTION; MANAGEMENT; COLLABORATION; INNOVATION; HEALTH; MODEL
AB The persistence of grand societal and environmental challenges demands attention from innovation management scholars and practitioners to find effective resolutions. Grand challenges are complex, uncertain, and evaluative and cannot be resolved by individual actors or organizations. Therefore, conventional forms of organizing do not suffice in the face of wicked problems like climate change or global inequality, which require continuous and varied attention and inputs. In this catalyst article, I argue that platform ecosystems-communities and groups of actors in different markets orchestrated through a digital platform and driven by combinations of economic and prosocial incentives-are an organizing form that can help effectively scale solutions for grand societal and environmental problems. This potential is based on three organizational elements of platform ecosystems: (1) coordination structures for orchestrating complementary inputs, (2) instigation and maintenance of collective action, and (3) generativity potential. I illustrate these arguments with practical examples of two platforms with the potential to resolve specific grand challenges: Patient Innovation, which orchestrates a community of innovators seeking to help treatment of chronic and rare diseases, and Excess Materials Exchange, which provides matching solutions to address the challenges associated with industrial material waste. The article concludes with an agenda for future research and practice on platform ecosystems and grand challenges.
